data.title: The Bj√∂rk Saga
data.meta_description: Read on for all you could possibly need to know about Iceland's musical Queen, the one and only Bj√∂rk!
data.text:
I talk, of course, of Bj√∂rk, an artist whose fierce attitude, inspiring madness and incomparable drive have made her name synonymous with Iceland. Reykjav√≠k-born and bred, Bj√∂rk‚Äôs cosmic wailings have brought staggering international attention to the country since the 1980s, ever building its reputation as home to some of the most imaginative artists found on the planet.

See also: The Sigur R√≥s Story | 18 Seconds Before Sunrise

In fact, her contribution has been so great that a grateful ex-prime minister, Dav√≠√∞ Oddsson, proposed in 2000 that Bj√∂rk should be given rights over the island of Elli√∞aey (the ensuing controversy meant the plan did not come to fruition, though the urban myth still persists).

Photo from Wikimedia, Creative Commons, by Failuresque. No edits made.

Still, her incredible success has done nothing to diminish her down-to-earth appreciation of her hometown, nor her family or the integrity of the work itself. Of living in Iceland, Bj√∂rk wrote in her forum, ‚Äú we don‚Äôt have much hierarchy and no-one is more important than the next one, therefore autographs are kinda silly. Here, it is a matter of self-respect.‚Äù

This respect is something the singer shares for her homeland, having on numerous occasions publicly attacked the perils of heavy industry and shown great solace toward the protection of the Icelandic highlands. ‚ÄúWhen I was a teenager I used to hitchhike and camp, and spend a few days on my own each year. The first money I got, when I was 13, I used to buy a tent. It was my ideal freedom. And I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm alone in that ideal. There‚Äôs a sacredness that comes with this landscape."

See also: Iceland's Troubled Environment

Still, Iceland was not enough to contain the singer‚Äôs talents or achievements. As of 2015, Bj√∂rk has sold somewhere in the region of 20 - 40 million albums, a truly staggering feat. But how did this young and creative Icelander go on to capture the hearts and minds of millions of music fans abroad?

Bjork's Early Life and Career

Born 21st November 1965, Bj√∂rk Gu√∞mundsd√≥ttir was raised by her mother, environmental activist, Hildur R√∫na Hauksd√≥ttir, after Hildur and her husband, Gu√∞mundur, divorced shortly after the birth.

Hildur moved with her daughter to a counter-culture oriented commune, where she quickly fell in love and remarried a guitar player, S√¶var √Årnason, renowned as the ‚ÄòJimi Hendrix of Iceland.‚Äô Artists and musicians commonly gathered in the family home to play music, swap stories and drink; it was from this early bohemian atmosphere where Bj√∂rk would draw much of her later influence.

Musically gifted as a child, from the age of six to fourteen Bj√∂rk attended Reykjav√≠k music college, Barnam√∫s√≠ksk√≥li, studying the classics and learning to play the piano and flute. It was here that Bj√∂rk had her first taste of a professional career as a musician.

At eleven years old, Bj√∂rk was one of many school children enrolled to sing or read a poem for the visiting parents. Bj√∂rk chose to sing Tina Charles‚Äô 1976 hit single, ‚ÄòI Love to Love (But My Baby Loves to Dance)‚Äô. Her rendition went down so well, her teachers chose to send a recording to Iceland‚Äôs one radio station, R√öV, who in turn elected it for national broadcast.

Photo from Wikimedia, Creative Commons, by Bruce McAdam. No edits made.

As fate would have it, the recording was heard by representatives of F√°lkinn (once a label, now a bicycle shop) who were quick to offer the young singer a record deal. Her 1977 debut album, Bj√∂rk, was recorded at Hlj√≥√∞riti Studios, consisting largely of cover songs translated into Icelandic; examples includes ‚ÄòYour Kiss is Sweet‚Äô by Stevie Wonder and ‚ÄòThe Fool on the Hill‚Äô by Lennon-McCartney.

The track ‚ÄòThe Arab Boy‚Äô was written by her stepfather, whilst the album cover was designed by Hildur, making the overall compilation a familial and collaborative effort. The album was given a limited release (at least 7000 copies) on both vinyl and cassette. Bj√∂rk was just twelve years old.

Upon the album‚Äôs entry into the Icelandic charts, Bj√∂rk became something of a reluctant child celebrity; friends at school were eager for her attention but failed to recognise the Bj√∂rk they idolised was quite different from the girl herself. Dejected, Bj√∂rk spent her social hours with musicians three times her age, many of whom encouraged from her a second album. It wasn‚Äôt until 1979, with the arrival of the Punk scene to Iceland, that Bj√∂rk would once again dip her toes into the world of music.

At fifteen years old, Bj√∂rk had become enamoured with the British hardcore punk outfit, Discharge. Eyebrows shaved, she formed the all-girl Riot band, Spit and Snot, though the group quickly disbanded due to ‚Äúattitude problems‚Äù and a tendency to sing only about their dislike of men.

A year later, she moved into her new band, a pop/new wave group called Exodus, whose legacy survives only on a single, garage-recorded cassette. Exodus was highlighted with a TV spot, putting Bj√∂rk in the limelight once again. After Exodus, she performed one gig with the band JAM80, though her tenure was short-lived.

Tappi T√≠karrass

Tappi T√≠karrass is generally considered to be Bj√∂rk‚Äôs first serious venture as a professional musician. The group‚Äôs name translates to Cork the Bitch‚Äôs Ass, (a reference to an early critique of the band‚Äôs music that it ‚Äúfitted like a cork in a bitch‚Äôs ass,‚Äù) and included Exodus bassist, Jakob Magn√∫sson. Though a punk outfit, the band brought together elements of rock, jazz and funk music, defying categorisation and setting an unspoken precedent for Bj√∂rk‚Äôs future career as an artist.

The band was active for two years and released one punk E.P, ‚ÄòBiti√∞ fast √≠ viti√∞‚Äô (1982), and later, a disco album, ‚ÄòMiranda‚Äô (1983). The group‚Äôs lightweight, melodic tracks were reminiscent of the early days of The Cure and thrust the band members into new realms of success. Yet, despite this newfound attention, Bj√∂rk‚Äôs vocals were still not yet fully explored or developed, lacking the throaty hollerings so common in her later work, both in The Sugarcubes and as a solo artist.

See also: Top 9 Most Famous Icelanders in History

Tappi T√≠karrass appeared in the Icelandic comedy film, ‚ÄòN√Ωtt l√≠f‚Äô (‚ÄòNew Life‚Äô 1983), directed by √ûr√°inn Bertelson, as well as featuring heavily in ‚ÄòRokk √≠ Reykjav√≠k‚Äô, a TV documentary directed by iconic Icelandic film director, Fri√∞rik √û√≥r Fri√∞riksson. Bj√∂rk contributed two songs to the film‚Äôs soundtrack and organically became the film‚Äôs major centrepiece, a resonating icon of that precious punk scene that rocked Iceland so heavily throughout the eighties.

Photo from Wikimedia, Creative Commons, by Rlef89. No edits made.

See also: The Story of Icelandic Cinema

K.U.K.L

In 1983, √Åsmundur J√≥nsson of Gramm Records formulated the idea of an Icelandic supergroup, enlisting Bj√∂rk as one of the leading vocalists. It was √Åsmundur‚Äôs intention that the band play live for the final episode of the radio show, √Åfangar; the experience was such a success, however, that the band mates enthusiastically agreed to make the group a permanent outfit, K.U.K.L (‚ÄòWitchcraft‚Äô in Medieval Icelandic).

A year later, their first album ‚ÄòThe Eye‚Äô (1984) was released, thanks in large part to the band‚Äôs connections with anarcho-punk groups in London. It was produced and distributed by Crass Records and was named after one of Bj√∂rk‚Äôs earliest influences, a sexually graphic (albeit, very good) novella entitled ‚ÄòStory of the Eye‚Äô by George Bataille (1922).

See also: Witchcraft and Sorcery in Iceland

The album reached number six on the UK Independent charts and received high praise from the critics; David Tibet of Sounds Magazine wrote of it ‚ÄúThe Eye steps boldly out of the supposed confines that the Crass label is meant to impose...and drags the listener into a glacial world of confused emotion and shattered visions.‚Äù

1984 and 1985 saw K.U.K.L tour Europe, playing L'Eldorado in Paris, Pandora‚Äôs Box Festival in the Netherlands and Roskilde Festival in Denmark. Throughout this period, the band collaborated with various artists including the rock singer Megas (though these recordings are still, as of yet, unreleased.)

K.U.K.L also made television appearances; one notable example was Bj√∂rk performing, seven months pregnant, in little more than her underwear. In 1986, the band released their second album with Crass Records, ‚ÄòHolidays in Europe (The Noughty Nought)‚Äô, a more complex record with a greater focus on electronic instruments, distortion effects and experimental noise.

Later that summer, the band‚Äôs trumpeter and vocalist, Einar √òrn, returned to Iceland from the UK to set up an entirely new record label, Bad Taste. With members of the band now pursuing other projects, K.U.K.L split up, though four of the original members would continue their collaboration with their new avantpop group; The Sugarcubes.

The Sugarcubes

Widely regarded as the greatest rock band to have ever come out of Iceland, The Sugarcubes were met with surprising, widespread critical acclaim upon the release of their first album ‚ÄòLife‚Äôs Too Good‚Äô (1986). They had formed the same year, on the very day Bj√∂rk and her then-husband, Thor Eldon (the band‚Äôs guitarist) welcomed their son into the world.

From the outset, the group was something new and edgy, their name even alluding to the ingestion of LSD. Signed onto the UK label, One Little Indian, and the US label, Elektra, their debut post-punk satire on the optimism of eighties pop propelled Bj√∂rk and the band to stardom, the signature single ‚ÄòBirthday‚Äô presenting them with the perfect opportunity to tour internationally.

In 1988, the band appeared on Saturday Night Live, as well as performing at The Ritz in New York City; they could even boast David Bowie and Iggy Pop as a fan of their musical outpourings. No musicians in Icelandic history had ever matched such a level of achievement.

The band‚Äôs second album, ‚ÄòHere Today, Tomorrow Next Week!‚Äô (1989) was less successful, however, with critics panning the group‚Äôs lack of development and deliberate attempt to stump their audience. Following a second international tour, the band considered splitting but instead chose to go on hiatus.

Photo from Wikimedia, Creative Commons, by Masao Nakagami. No edits made.

The Sugarcubes‚Äô third and final album, ‚ÄòStick Around For Joy‚Äô (1990), was met with higher praise and birthed the band‚Äôs major hit single, the ironically titled ‚ÄòHit.‚Äô During the leg of their Zoo TV Tour, the band opened for U2, thus performing in front of over 700,000 people, by far their largest audience to date. Still, no level of accomplishment could save the band from splitting up, and in 1992, they did just that.

The Sugarcubes reunited briefly in 2006 to play a concert in Reykjav√≠k, raising money for the Bad Taste label and to help continue promoting Icelandic music. The band has made it clear, however, that there are no future plans for recording or performing new tracks.

Bjork's Solo Career

In the space intermittent between the break up of The Sugarcubes and Bj√∂rk‚Äôs second solo outing, the story has over time become cloaked in myth and inaccuracy. To quantify the debts raised by The Sugarcubes throughout the eighties, some claim Bj√∂rk went to work in an antique shop, others that she ran a market stall.

Regardless of the truth, Bj√∂rk‚Äôs commitment to a future in music was undiminished. Little did she know then, her time to break out as a solo artist was fast approaching; the world of music would never be the same again.

Debut (1993), Post (1994) and Telegram (1996)

Whilst in the dying day of The Sugarcubes, Bj√∂rk sent a demo cassette of her own songs to Bad Taste. Of that period, Bj√∂rk has stated, ‚ÄúI realised that it was now or never. Either I record all those songs which had been floating in my head for years, otherwise, I'd never do it.‚Äù

Once the band was on hiatus, Bj√∂rk moved to London where she was quickly introduced to a music scene, perhaps, better suited to her tastes than that projected by The Sugarcubes; Brian Eno, Kate Bush, Acid House... an almost endless list.

Her first album, ‚ÄòDebut‚Äô (1993) was produced by Nellee Hopper, a professional famous for his work with Soul II Soul and Massive Attack. Though initially reluctant to work with the producer (the initial concept was to use multiple producers), Bj√∂rk was quickly inspired by his ideas and the pair spent many studio sessions writing and recording numbers for the album.

Reaction upon the album‚Äôs release was generally positive; breaking the status quo of the electronic/dance music so popular in the early nineties, Bj√∂rk won ‚ÄòBest Newcomer‚Äô and ‚ÄòBest International Female‚Äô at the 1994 Brit Awards.

Bj√∂rk‚Äôs second album saw a noticeable development in her songwriting and composition; unlike 'Debut', where the songs had been written in Iceland, 'Post' was intended to convey the fast-paced and eclectic energy of the singer‚Äôs new home in London. Unlike the album‚Äôs predecessor, numerous producers collaborated on the album, including Graham Massey of 808 State and Massive Attack‚Äôs Tricky.

Despite being regarded as an experimental album with a wide range of emotional overtones, listeners still found 'Post' to be accessible and endearing, praising the tracks for their adventurous and club-friendly nature.

Following 'Post', Bj√∂rk released her first full-length remix album, 'Telegram', even though the singer herself fails to classify it that way; ‚ÄúFor me, Telegram is really Post as well but all the elements of the songs are just exaggerated. It's like the core of Post. That's why it's funny to call it a remix album, it's like the opposite. Telegram is more stark, naked. Not trying to make it pretty or peaceable for the ear. Just a record I would buy myself.‚Äù

Telegram, having failed to break much new ground, was upon its release disappointing to critics who felt as though Bj√∂rk was merely basking in the comforts of her own reputation.

Homogenic (1999) and Stalking Incident

In 1996, tragedy struck in the form of Ricardo Lopez, a mentally-ill pest control officer living in Florida. Trapped by feelings of inferiority and self-loathing, Ricardo had since eighteen kept himself a recluse, nurturing and feeding into his dangerous obsessions with women in the public eye. Having previously stalked a young American actress, Lopez quickly fixated himself on the Icelandic artist after seeing her by chance in a music video.

Initially, Lopez contented himself with researching the singer‚Äôs life and writing her fan mail, claiming his infatuation with her filled him with a sense of euphoria. Around this time, he also began to fill out what would eventually be an 803-page diary detailing his self-critical thoughts, feelings of inadequacy and haunting plans regarding the singer.

After reading of Bj√∂rk's relationship with UK producer, Goldie, Lopez felt deeply betrayed and angered, the relationship inflaming his already dangerous views on race. It was then that he decided to kill her; in his Florida home, Lopez began to document the construction of a letter bomb, hidden inside of a hollowed out book.

Lopez sent the package ostensibly through the singer‚Äôs record label, then committed suicide. Upon the police‚Äôs discovery of his body and the subsequent, confessional material alongside him, the FBI immediately set about disposing of the bomb. The package had already made its way to England but was sitting in a South London post office. Safely, the Metropolitan police intercepted the package before anyone could be hurt.

See also: Of Monsters and Men | A Melodic Odyssey

Understandably, Bj√∂rk was highly distressed by the incident; by how close she and her son had come to danger; by how intricately strangers could entangle themselves in her personal life. Quickly, the singer hired security for her son, as well as a minder to take him to and from school. To avoid the ensuing media attention, Bj√∂rk left for Spain to concentrate on writing and recording her third solo album.

The Homogenic album was to sound like ‚Äúrough volcanoes with moss growing over them.‚Äù Throughout the span of her career, Homogenic is widely regarded as Bj√∂rk‚Äôs finest moment as an artist, laying down the lengthy melodies, sonics and eerily personal lyrics that have since made the singer so iconic. Having departed from working with her producer Nellee Hopper, Homogenic was a collaborative effort by numerous producers.

Homogenic was nominated for Best Alternative Musical Performance at the 1999 Grammy Awards, with Slant Magazine claiming ‚Äúif not the greatest electronic album of all time, it‚Äôs certainly the greatest of the decade.‚Äù Bj√∂rk also won the Best International Female at the Brit Awards, to which she thanked the audience by saying famously ‚ÄúI am grateful grapefruit.‚Äù

Dancer in the Dark & Selmasongs (2000)

In 2000, Bj√∂rk played her first lead role of Selma in Lars Von Trier‚Äôs musical ‚ÄòDancer in the Dark‚Äô. The director had spent nearly a year trying to persuade Bj√∂rk to take the part; the singer was concerned that she was ‚Äúa music artist, not a cinema artist.‚Äù Little did he know how contentious the pair‚Äôs relationship would ultimately become.

The shoot has become infamous regarding Bj√∂rk‚Äôs erratic behaviour on set. Lars Von Trier has testified that each morning before shooting, Bj√∂rk would approach him and say ‚ÄúMr Von Trier, I despise you,‚Äù before spitting at him.

On the other side of the dispute, Bj√∂rk would claim Von Trier to be sexist and impossible to work with. Regardless, she would also leave the set mysteriously for three days, causing numerous production delays and was suspected of having eaten parts of her costume. As Bj√∂rk stated herself, the experience was emotionally taxing.

Von Trier was also planning on casting himself as an angry character whose only purpose in the film is to chastise Selma. However, due to the pair‚Äôs reactive chemistry, the director decided to cast another actor in fear that he would overact, thus putting the production into jeopardy.

Despite vowing never to act again, Bj√∂rk won the Best Actress award at Cannes Film Festival that year. The film was enormously polarising, with some hailing the highbrow, artistic direction whilst others condemned it as pretentious and shallow.

To coincide with the film‚Äôs release, Bj√∂rk released the album 'Selmasongs'. The album was met with favourable reviews, though like the film, it had a polarising effects on critics; reviews ranged from ‚ÄúSelmasongs is mostly show tunes on Ecstasy, and you keep praying for a police raid" to ‚ÄúSelmasongs paints a portrait of a woman losing her sight, but it maintains Bj√∂rk's unique vision.‚Äù

The song ‚ÄòI‚Äôve Seen it All‚Äô was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Original Song; at the awards ceremony, Bj√∂rk wore the now iconic ‚Äòswan dress‚Äô and proceeded to drop from it onto the red carpet a large Ostrich egg.

The late and lovely comedienne, Joan Rivers, remarked of the incident, "Later I saw her in the ladies room spreading papers on the floor‚Ä¶This girl should be put into an asylum‚Äù The swan dress would later make a reappearance on the cover of Bj√∂rk‚Äôs fourth solo album, Vespertine.

Photo from Wikimedia, Creative Commons, by Christia Del Riccio. No edits made.

Vespertine (2001)

Vespertine was shaped largely by two defining and paradoxical factors in Bj√∂rk‚Äôs life; her strenuous stint working under Lars Von Trier and her new relationship with sculpturist, photographer and filmmaker, Matthew Barney. Both experiences pushed her artistically to write songs that were intimate, emotional and revealing, a further step away from Bj√∂rk's era as the queen of dancehall music.

Work on the album began during the production of 'Dancer in the Dark', with Bj√∂rk claiming that whilst 'Selmasongs' felt like work, 'Vespertine' was a hobby. The tranquil and hushed tones of 'Vespertine' were an expression of escape from the extroverted character she was made to play on set. Sitting for hours alone at her computer, 'Vespertine' would become known as Bj√∂rk's "laptop album", an electronica record that touched upon the domesticity of everyday life.

The album was an enormous critical success, sensationalising new and old listeners alike with the singer‚Äôs sensual, erotic lyrics and multi-layered, rhythmic instrumentation. The album reached number 8 on the UK Albums chart and number 19 on the US Billboard 200, as well as reaching Gold Certification in the UK, France and Canada.

Fourteen years later, Bj√∂rk would tell Pitchfork magazine of her irritation at others failing to recognise the individual auteurship she had over her albums, writing "I did 80% of the beats on Vespertine and it took me three years to work on that album, because it was all microbeats ‚Äî it was like doing a huge embroidery piece. Matmos came in the last two weeks and added percussion on top of the songs, but they didn't do any of the main parts, and they are credited everywhere as having done the whole album."

Throughout her career, Bj√∂rk has been vocal regarding the gender double standards in the music industry, though it is only of late that she has reclaimed the feminist label; in 2015, the singer famously retorted, "Everything that a guy says once, you have to say five times." Hoping to inspire and advise young women, Bj√∂rk cited her time as lead vocalist in The Sugarcubes as a perfect example of how new female musicians often struggle to be recognised over their male counterparts.

See also: Gender Equality in Iceland

Med√∫lla (2004) & Drawing Restraint (2005)

'Med√∫lla' is distinctive amongst Bj√∂rk's body of work in so much that the album is largely a cappella, constructed using various vocals and effects. At the time of release, Bj√∂rk claimed this to be her most outright political album, an attempt to counter the resurgence of nationalism that manifested after the September 11th attacks in New York City.

The album would be nominated for two Grammy Awards and reached number 1 on numerous charts around the world. There was, however, no promotional tour to coincide with the album‚Äôs release because Bj√∂rk believed the songs would be too difficult to perform live. Instead, the singer was commissioned by the Olympic Committee to perform for the 2004 games in Athens. Bj√∂rk performed the song ‚ÄòOceania,‚Äô her dress unfurling throughout the song‚Äôs duration until it filled the entire stage, revealing a map of a unified world.

Bj√∂rk returned to the world of acting to star in her then-husband's art-house feature, ‚ÄòDrawing Restraint 9.‚Äô The film, an abstract examination of Japanese culture, featured no dialogue but instead stylistically conveyed the narrative through sculpture, music and conceptual imagery.

Bj√∂rk also produced the film‚Äôs soundtrack, marking the second time she worked directly under the influence of cinema. She also appeared in another film that year, the documentary Screaming Masterpiece, where she discussed the Icelandic music scene.

Volta (2007) & Volta√Øc (2009)

The recording of Bj√∂rk's sixth solo album began shortly after her return from Banda Aceh, Indonesia, where she was observing UNICEF work with child victims of the Boxing Day Tsunami. This experience was an enormous influence on the track, "Earth Intruders", originally a ten minute, loosely improvised number that was later edited down for the album. Bj√∂rk also released the charity album 'Army of Me: Remixes and Covers' to fund the charity effort in Indonesia.

'Volta' was welcomed by critics as a return to Bj√∂rk‚Äôs talent as a pop musician. Having previously worked on three serious and emotional projects, the singer felt she needed to release an album that was more commercial, up-tempo and fun. Volta was a largely collaborative venture, with Bj√∂rk bringing in such artists and producers as Mark Bell, Timbaland and Danja to work on the music.

As fate would have it, the album was accidentally released two weeks prior to its official release date. The album was online for six hours before being taken down; unfortunately, in the age of the internet, this was more than enough time for the album to be leaked. Regardless, Bj√∂rk began to promote the album with an international tour and received a nomination for Best Alternative Music Album at the Grammy Awards.

Her follow-up, 'Volta√Øc', saw the release of five related materials to Volta, including a live DVD, a DVD of Volta music videos and 2 CDs (one a remix of Volta, the other a recording of eleven songs from the Olympics).

Biophilia (2011), Vulnicura (2015) to Present Day

Photo from Wikimedia, Creative Commons, by Laganjart. No edits made.

'Biophilia', officially regarded as Bj√∂rk's seventh solo outing, is her first 'concept album'. Composed during the fallout of the 2008-2011 Icelandic financial crisis, the artist set about creating a multimedia project that explored the relationships between nature and technology. In that vein, Bj√∂rk released the album through a series of apps, further testing the potentials of how music can be distributed to the listener.

The album was an enormous success; named Album of the Year by numerous music publications, it won Best Recording Package at the 55th Grammy Awards and debuted in the top 40 of almost every international chart. The compilation would also spawn two remix albums.

Alongside the release of her 'Biophilia' album, Bj√∂rk set about distributing a phone application, later adapted into the Biophilia Educational Program. The program‚Äôs primary intention was to allow children to connect with their own creativity through science, music and the latest technology. Upon the release of her album, the singer engaged in educational workshops on four continents.

In classic Bj√∂rk style, the venture has been executed with a technician's attention to detail, and with an artist‚Äôs flair for experimentation. The project has been such a success, in fact, that many schools around Scandinavia have adopted it as part of the curriculum.

Her eighth studio album, 'Vulnicura', emotively divulged in Bj√∂rk's break up with Matthew Barney and the ensuing custody battle regarding their daughter. Three years following her last effort, the album was highly anticipated by music publications and fans alike, with NME claiming 2015 would be the year of Bj√∂rk's major comeback.

The album was produced by Venezuelan producer, Arca, incorporating elements of experimental electronica and ambient music; many critics felt the album was reminiscent of 1997's Homogenic. The album's major inclusion of string compositions was something of a healing process for the artist; "The only way I could deal with that was to start writing for strings; I decided to become a violin nerd and arrange everything for 15 strings and take a step further."

To coincide, Bj√∂rk‚Äôs latest album has once again seen her exploring new realms of the creative process. Her latest virtual reality project - BJORK DIGITAL - blends the newest experimental melodies with modern technology, creating a psychedelic, moving exhibition that further builds on Bj√∂rk‚Äôs reputation as an artist forever on the cutting edge.

2017 has seen Bj√∂rk touring, performing in such places as Spain, Japan and the United States. Sadly, her final tour dates are in July, meaning you'll have to be patient if seeing Bj√∂rk live is a major goal on the bucket list.

Whatever the world can expect from Bj√∂rk ‚Äì be it music, film, exhibitions or something entirely new ‚Äì it is guaranteed that there is a legion of fans out there still to be further inspired by the artist's unwavering creativity.

If you happen to see Bj√∂rk on your visit (she does frequent the Reykjav√≠k bar scene from time to time,) I suggest you appreciate her from a distance. If there is one thing Bj√∂rk is infamous for, after all, it is peculiar first impressions.
